comments.commentBody: I believe you are misreading Mr. Egan.  Here is the statement from the column which you refer to:   "People who play in the American outdoors spend $646 billion a year, responsible for 6.1 million jobs."  I interpret this to mean more than just purchasing the equipment needed for those activities.  For example national parks all have fees and many who travel to these places spend money on motels, food, guides, gas to get there, etc, etc, etc.  The even larger point is that we as a group are in fact a constituency which along side other traditional constituencies like the gas & oil industry, cattle, mining, and development may finally have a receptive ear in the Interior department and that we should as a group make our point of view and voice heard.

While I think the nomination of the CEO of REI to be the next Secretary of the Interior is a brilliant idea--and the idea that the department would focus not just on those who seek to profit from the extraction or exploitation of the nation's lands--but those who seek to enjoy them beyond refreshing--I have to quibble with Mr. Egan's stats when he claims that "....Americans spend more money on outdoor equipment than they do on pharmaceuticals or gasoline."

A 2012 study by the Outdoor Industry Association--a group that I suspect would see some advantage in accentuating the importance of the industry to America's economy--concluded that last year Americans spend $110 billion on "outdoor equipment."

Compared to an estimated $310 billion plus spend on pharmaceuticals.

And $700 billion on gas.

What are the sources Mr. Egan is using?

Bill while I agree that tar sands oil development and burning are respectively a local environmental disaster in British Columbia and globally a disaster in regards to climate change, the primary responsibility and blame belongs to the Canadians.  After all there would be no need for a pipeline if not for the decision by Canadians to develop this incredibly destructive fossil fuel.  I oppose the XL (or any other pipeline) that would bring this product to the US for refinement, but I doubt that will prevent its ultimate refinement somewhere, even if the Canadians have to build the refineries themselves.  President Obama's decision may delay final refinement of this product but it ultimately won't stop it. That my Canadian friend is up to you, your like minded citizens, and Canadian environmentalists.

Unfortunately, the tar sands oil will be burned with or without the Keystone pipeline. The crude will be shipped to refineries by rail,
a much riskier proposition than the pipeline.

Todd, Richard:

The Northern Gateway pipeline to the BC coast is being vigorously opposed by a broad coalition and could conceivably be stopped, as could expansion of the capacity of the Kinder Morgan pipeline to Vancouver.

Alberta seems determined to export tar sands bitumin, but they are landlocked, and whatever means they try to use within Canada will be met with stiff opposition.

Keystone XL crosses directly into the US from Alberta, however, so for all intent and purposes it is the US that has to shut it down: no market no pipeline.

While it is true that transport to Canadian refineries in eastern Canada for domestic consumption could be a fallback plan for continued tar sands development, that bridge will be addressed if necessary.

The XL Pipeline is a fuse to a carbon bomb that will doom humanity if it is allowed to go off and all that Alberta tar sands oil is burned.

This is the one issue where President Obama can show his true colors with regard to global warming.

If he doesn't shut the XL down, he will have zero credibility on CO2 from here on out.

The U.S. isn't Australia in that Australia's economy is doing much better, that is, it isn't in a low-demand caused liquidity trap and is not as far from full employment as the U.S. economy is. That means that there is already strong demand for labor, which will support a higher minimum wage.

But the U.S. is different. Here slack demand raises two problems: First, can businesses, especially the one's with a high proportion of low wage workers make a sufficient profit to warrant a decision to continue to employ worker at $10.00/hr, and second--and this is connected to the First--if you increase the minimum wage to $10.00/hr., will low wages worker even have enough purchasing power to increase consumption enough to increase demand and will they use enough of their increased wages for consumption that sufficiently increases demand. Now, I am less concerned about worker spending their increased wages for consumption, because the working poor must consume their wages just to get by. But moving the minimum wage up to $10.00, even if workers spend all of the increase, simply might not be enough purchasing power to increase demand.

The more certain, and more direct course is for the U.S. to do adequate fiscal stimulus first and have that adequately increase demand for goods, services, and, consequently, labor. After all increasing demand is what you wish to do, and an adequate fiscal stimulus does that, while increasing the minimum wage may not.

Most of the comments here convey poignant experiences with autism, but this story touched me in a different way. My husband and I have been married almost 32 years and we have a 24 year old son (our only child) who became mysteriously ill about ten years ago. Our son lives with us and struggles daily with an extremely painful, debilitating, and degenerative neurological disease called pandysautonomia. The doctors don't understand the disease very well and we have struggled for a long time, not only with the disease and its emotional stresses, but with the lack of a support group. So few people have this disease, and the ones afflicted as badly as our son usually are elderly.

I saw this story and thought, "there are other boomer couples who care daily for their seriously disabled adult children." I knew in theory that was true, but I don't personally know any couples in that situation. So this headline jumped out at me and the story touched me.

Life serves such unpredictable combinations of joy and sadness. Our son's disease has brought all three of us so much sadness. The worst for me is when he cries out in pain (almost every day) and there's nothing I can do to stop the pain. But there have also been so many moments of pure joy and love--in hospital rooms, in the darkest moments, in the most unexpected places. Sometimes I think that the only power we have against this suffering is to feel compassion and support for one another.

Since Canada won't be able to support the encroaching population of migrants, they could simply feed them to the polar bears, solving two problems at once.

Seriously folks, I'm as disturbed about the plight of the the polar bears as anyone else. (Along with the rest of the world's biota, not just the "charismatic megafauna.")

But this entire discussion is based on the false premise that there can be adaption to climate change without mitigation of climate change. The opposite is true: without mitigation, there will be no adaption because conditions will get progressively worse at an accelerating pace. Any adaption strategies will remain behind the curve.

It's good to think about what we can do for the bears, but we can't just throw up our hands and say, "Well, we're not going to do anything about climate change," so let's set aside some icy reserve. How long until it, too melts away or is invaded by trolls trawling for oil?

Humans will be so busy scrambling to survive the effects of climate change — estimated in monetary terms alone to be in the trillions in coming decades — that they will have no time for bears.

It's either mitigation now or, as Dr. Hansen has put it, "game over" for the bears and the rest of us.
